Award.AwardTitle: Workshop for Chairs of STEM Departments: Improving Undergraduate STEM Teaching and Learning in Research Universities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Since 2011, the Association of American Universities (AAU), a coalition of 62 distinguished research universities in the United States and Canada, has engaged in a major initiative to improve the quality of undergraduate STEM education at AAU member universities. It has focused on improving STEM education by encouraging faculty members to use teaching methods that have been proven to be effective. The academic departments of these universities are central to making improvements in undergraduate teaching and learning, because the culture and norms within departments greatly influence how courses are taught. The chairs of the STEM departments benefit from guidance about how to cultivate departmental cultures that value and encourage the use of evidence-based teaching practices, and how to reward faculty members for innovative teaching efforts. To provide such guidance, this project will conduct a two-day workshop in October 2018 for STEM department chairs from AAU universities.

The workshop will be designed to assist department chairs in identifying challenges and practical solutions related to implementing long-lasting teaching improvements. Participants will learn about successful strategies that have been used to facilitate department-wide reform of undergraduate STEM teaching and learning. The information and discussions will be designed to prompt the chairs to think more deeply about their roles in encouraging and implementing reform efforts in their departments and across their campuses. Subsequent actions of the chairs in their departments has the potential to improve undergraduate STEM teaching and learning on the AAU member campuses and develop visible models for other institutions. The findings and conclusions from the workshop will be widely shared with other department chairs, faculty members, and senior leaders at AAU institutions, as well as the broader higher education community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since September 2011, the Association of American Universities (AAU) has been engaged in a major initiative to improve the quality and effectiveness of undergraduate teaching and learning in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields at AAU universities. Through this work, AAU has come to recognize that department cultures and practices are central to improving undergraduate teaching and learning, and therefore to identify academic departments as the loci for educational change. In their leadership role, department chairs play a key part in influencing faculty to either be a source of energy and creativity for undergraduate teaching reform, or to be change resistant. 

            As AAU has engaged with member campuses over the years it has become evident that STEM department chairs often need guidance on how to effectively cultivate department cultures in which undergraduate teaching is valued and teaching innovation is rewarded. Moreover, research has shown that merely sharing evidence about best practices often does not result in changes in higher education, but rather relationships and networks coupled with information sharing more strongly promotes changes in ideas and practices. Therefore, to help with these issues, AAU organized and successfully facilitated two workshops (one in 2015 and another in 2018) specifically for AAU STEM department chairs on improving undergraduate education. Grant award number 1822046 funded the most recent workshop held on October 14-16, 2018 in California.

            In total, 77 individuals participated in the October 2018 workshop, which included over 60 STEM department chairs from 25 AAU member universities. The discussion-based workshop fostered dialogue among participants within and across institutions and disciplinary areas that helped them to think deeply about new ways to bolster and implement reform efforts on their campuses and in their departments. Participants indicated in the workshop evaluation that the opportunity to discuss challenges and practical solutions related to undergraduate teaching reform with peers from other AAU institutions was highly productive and worthwhile. 

            AAU staff have shared emergent findings and outcomes from the workshop that can help improve undergraduate STEM teaching and learning within the wider AAU campus community and beyond. In addition to communicating information at AAU constituency group meetings and via email to the broader AAU STEM Network, workshop findings have been shared with individuals from other higher education associations, federal agencies, professional societies and multi-institutional initiatives that AAU staff regularly interact with at meetings and coalitions around supporting systemic change in undergraduate STEM education. Moreover, using insights, finding and outcomes gained from the convening, AAU is in the process of developing a guide for department chairs that will be available to January 2021 AAU STEM department chair workshop participants. 

            To continue conversations after the conclusion of the meeting, AAU staff have visited member campuses to have follow-up discussions with department chairs, faculty members and senior leaders. From our correspondence with campuses, AAU has learned that many department chairs are sharing workshop resource materials and information with faculty members to initiate conversations about effective teaching, and engaging colleagues in offices across campus such as those in centers for teaching and learning, and data analytics to support teaching improvement efforts both within and across their departments.    

            Going forward, AAU plans to convene a workshop for AAU STEM department chairs biennially, on alternating years from when AAU hosts a conference for AAU STEM Network members at-large. With this sustainable structure, AAU will consistently support systemic improvements in undergraduate STEM education at research-intensive institutions by promoting and disseminating effective teaching practices and by fostering relationships around undergraduate education among department chairs, faculty and administrators.  Ultimately, this work will help to scale successful innovations across departments, disciplines, institutions, and regions.
